Comments: "Inception," at its most basic, is two things. It is a heist film dressed in science fiction conventions; and it is a study of a man trying to free himself from a near-suffocating past. "Inception," at its more complex, is a cerebral pop-masterpiece. It is an enthralling combination of thought-provoking, layered story-telling and sumptuous aesthetics enhanced by near-flawless editing, sound design, effects, and musical score. Driven by a pitch-perfect cast and the confident directorial hand of Christopher Nolan, "Inception" is a brilliant and unrivaled piece of filmmaking.

Inception is a brilliant film. Christopher Nolan twists our minds in millions of pieces with this complex film. He knows how to combine true spectacular direction, with symbolic concepts about our perception of reality as how we can trap ourselves in lives and ideas that don't necessarily reflect the reality. Leonardo DiCaprio does a fantastic job. The "dream world" dream within' a dream moments and the theory of time slowing are fun mind puzzles to unravel. The action is well paced and suspenseful. The music score and settings all flow together well. Overall, Inception is excellent.

One of the most memorable Mystery/Sci-Fi flicks from the 2010's, this is a clever and entertaining Hollywood spectacle as orchestrated by the always competent Christopher Nolan. While I don't personally adore it as much as other people, I can only recognize its qualities and the final scene perfectly suited to Hans Zimmer's "Epic and not at all subtle but we love him for it Score" still remains one of the best "frustrating yet absolutely perfect" ending ever put to film.

Inception is absolutely the greatest movie I have ever seen in my entire life. I must clarify though that I have only seen five other movies all the way through and one of those is four episodes of Californication back to back so idk if that counts. Inception is that rare movie that reaches new heights of cinema and visual art. It is inspiring as fuck and that is why I am proud to announce it made me realize my new passion in life: I am moving to Hollywood tomorrow to find Christopher Nolan and make him teach me how to direct mindfuck movies.

Is this the unquestionable peak of dudebro, "well, actually..." cinema? Of course it is, and unashamedly so. That said, however, 2010 me was all head over heels for the slick aesthetics and practical, stunt-driven sci-fi spectacle. A decade on, 2020 me is still about all of those things, but now I'm also out here with mad respect for the finely-tuned, matryoshka frame narratives that sing and resonate with each resounding Zimmer "BRRAAAMMMM". Paradox indeed.

Coupled with an excellent cast, superb set pieces and the fact that Nolan manages to squeeze some emotion into the mix, Inception is Hollywood filmmaking done well.
Was looking forward to my (just) second viewing of it, but now can clearly say, that INTERSTELLAR was quiet a jump in Nolans oevre. I did forget how much Nolan is/was into pure Genre Cinema (part 2).

Short Review: Style meets substance. They get married and spent 50 years in subconscious limbo, playing God and creating all manner of awesome structures. Then they have a falling-out and try to kill each other, chasing each other through complex labyrinths. Then they wake up from one dream after another after another, meticulously crafting a sublime plot with a ton of deep ideas as they do so. That's just how cool this film is.
Inception.
